markdownRemark.html:
§ Methods of Weighted Residual to Obtain Governing Weak Form

Consider: −(ku^′)′+bu^′+cu^=f-(k\hat{u}')'+b\hat{u}'+c\hat{u}=f−(ku^′)′+bu^′+cu^=f Residual: r(u^)=−(ku^′)′+bu^′+cu^−fr(\hat{u})=-(k\hat{u}')'+b\hat{u}'+c\hat{u}-fr(u^)=−(ku^′)′+bu^′+cu^−f Multiply by test function v such that v and u are in the same space (thus v also satisfies EBC) and integrate over domain:

∫0Lr(u^)vdx=0→∫0L[−(ku^′)′+bu^′+cu^−f]vdx=0\int_0^L r(\hat{u})vdx = 0 \rightarrow \int_0^L [-(k\hat{u}')'+b\hat{u}'+c\hat{u}-f]vdx=0 ∫0L​r(u^)vdx=0→∫0L​[−(ku^′)′+bu^′+cu^−f]vdx=0

Suppose v is sufficiently smooth so that we can integrate the 1st term by parts: ∫0L−(ku^′)′vdx=−(ku^′)v∣0L+∫0Lku^′v′dx\int_0^L -(k\hat{u}')'vdx=-(k\hat{u}')v|^L_0 + \int_0^Lk\hat{u}'v'dx∫0L​−(ku^′)′vdx=−(ku^′)v∣0L​+∫0L​ku^′v′dx

Suppose the initial boundary is zero, then u(0)=0, it follows that that v at x=0 must also be 0 and we have

∫0Lku^′v′dx+∫0Lcu^vdx−∫0Lfvdx−Tvv(L)=0\int_0^L k\hat{u}'v'dx + \int_0^Lc\hat{u}vdx - \int_0^Lfvdx - T_vv(L)=0∫0L​ku^′v′dx+∫0L​cu^vdx−∫0L​fvdx−Tv​v(L)=0

§ Numerical Approximation: Galerkin Method in Weak Form

Let u^∼uN=∑k=1Nαkϕk(x)\hat{u} \sim u_N = \sum_{k=1}^N \alpha_k \phi_k(x)u^∼uN​=∑k=1N​αk​ϕk​(x), then u^∼uN=∑i=1Nβiϕi(x)\hat{u} \sim u_N = \sum_{i=1}^N \beta_i \phi_i(x)u^∼uN​=∑i=1N​βi​ϕi​(x)

∫0Lk(∑k=1Nαkϕk′(x))(∑i=1Nβiϕi′(x))dx+∫0Lc(∑k=1Nαkϕk(x))(∑i=1Nβiϕi(x))dx−∫0Lf(∑i=1Nβiϕi(x))dx−Tv(∑i=1Nβiϕi(L))dx\int_0^L k \left( \sum_{k=1}^N \alpha_k \phi_k'(x) \right)\left( \sum_{i=1}^N \beta_i \phi_i'(x) \right)dx + \int_0^L c \left( \sum_{k=1}^N \alpha_k \phi_k(x) \right)\left( \sum_{i=1}^N \beta_i \phi_i(x) \right)dx - \int_0^L f \left( \sum_{i=1}^N \beta_i \phi_i(x) \right)dx-T_v \left( \sum_{i=1}^N \beta_i \phi_i(L) \right)dx∫0L​k(∑k=1N​αk​ϕk′​(x))(∑i=1N​βi​ϕi′​(x))dx+∫0L​c(∑k=1N​αk​ϕk​(x))(∑i=1N​βi​ϕi​(x))dx−∫0L​f(∑i=1N​βi​ϕi​(x))dx−Tv​(∑i=1N​βi​ϕi​(L))dx Let Kkj=∫0Lk(x)ϕj′(x)ϕk′(x)dx=KjkK_{kj}=\int_0^L k(x)\phi_j'(x)\phi_k'(x)dx=K_{jk}Kkj​=∫0L​k(x)ϕj′​(x)ϕk′​(x)dx=Kjk​ Ckj=∫0Lc(x)ϕj(x)ϕk(x)dxC_{kj}=\int_0^Lc(x)\phi_j(x)\phi_k(x)dxCkj​=∫0L​c(x)ϕj​(x)ϕk​(x)dx fk=∫0Lfϕk(x)dx+ϕk(L)f_k=\int_0^L f\phi_k(x)dx+\phi_k(L)fk​=∫0L​fϕk​(x)dx+ϕk​(L) The final equation to solve for is ∑iBi{∑k(Kjk+Cjk)ak−fi}=0→{∑k(Kjk+Cjk)ak−fi}=0∀Bi,i=1,…,n\sum_i B_i \left\{ \sum_k (K_{jk}+C_{jk})a_k -f_i \right\}=0 \rightarrow \left\{ \sum_k (K_{jk}+C_{jk})a_k -f_i \right\}=0 \forall B_i, \quad i=1, \dotsc ,n∑i​Bi​{∑k​(Kjk​+Cjk​)ak​−fi​}=0→{∑k​(Kjk​+Cjk​)ak​−fi​}=0∀Bi​,i=1,…,n The goal is to solve for αk\alpha_kαk​ in Dα=fD\alpha=fDα=f where Djk=Kjk+CjkD_{jk}=K_{jk}+C_{jk}Djk​=Kjk​+Cjk​

§ Selecting Appropriate Basic Functions

Trial functions: Un(x)=∑i=1nαiϕi(x)U_n(x)=\sum_{i=1}^n \alpha_i \phi_i(x)Un​(x)=∑i=1n​αi​ϕi​(x) Test functions: Vn(x)=∑i=1nβiXi(x)V_n(x)=\sum_{i=1}^n \beta_i X_i(x)Vn​(x)=∑i=1n​βi​Xi​(x) How do we choose a ϕ(x)\phi(x)ϕ(x) such that u^\hat{u}u^ satisfies the boundary conditions?

Local Functions: {ϕAe(ξ)=−12(ξ)(1−ξ)ϕBe(ξ)=12(ξ)(1+ξ)ϕCe(ξ)=(1−xi)(1+ξ)\left\{ \begin{array}{c} \phi_A^e(\xi)=-\frac{1}{2}(\xi)(1-\xi)\\ \phi_B^e(\xi)=\frac{1}{2}(\xi)(1+\xi)\\ \phi_C^e(\xi)=(1-xi)(1+\xi)\\ \end{array} \right.⎩⎨⎧​ϕAe​(ξ)=−21​(ξ)(1−ξ)ϕBe​(ξ)=21​(ξ)(1+ξ)ϕCe​(ξ)=(1−xi)(1+ξ)​

If we notice that x=xc+ξh2→ξ=2(x−xc)2x=x_c+\xi \frac{h}{2} \rightarrow \xi=\frac{2(x-x_c)}{2}x=xc​+ξ2h​→ξ=22(x−xc​)​

{ϕAe(ξ)=−x(xC)hh−2x+2xC)hϕBe(ξ)=x(xC)hh+2x−2xC)hϕCe(ξ)=h−2x+2xChh+2x+2xC)h→{ϕAe(ξ)=(xC−x)(xB−x)(xC−xA)(xB−xA)ϕBe(ξ)=(xA−x)(xB−x)(xA−xC)(xB−x−C)ϕCe(ξ)=(xA−x)(xC−x)(xA−xB)(xC−xB)\left\{ \begin{array}{c} \phi_A^e(\xi)=\frac{-x(x_C)}{h} \frac{h-2x+2x_C)}{h}\\ \phi_B^e(\xi)=\frac{x(x_C)}{h} \frac{h+2x-2x_C)}{h}\\ \phi_C^e(\xi)=\frac{h-2x+2x_C}{h} \frac{h+2x+2x_C)}{h}\\ \end{array} \right. \to \left\{ \begin{array}{c} \phi_A^e(\xi)=\frac{(x_C-x)(x_B-x)}{(x_C-x_A)(x_B-x_A)}\\ \phi_B^e(\xi)=\frac{(x_A-x)(x_B-x)}{(x_A-x_C)(x_B-x-C)}\\ \phi_C^e(\xi)=\frac{(x_A-x)(x_C-x)}{(x_A-x_B)(x_C-x_B)}\\ \end{array} \right.⎩⎨⎧​ϕAe​(ξ)=h−x(xC​)​hh−2x+2xC​)​ϕBe​(ξ)=hx(xC​)​hh+2x−2xC​)​ϕCe​(ξ)=hh−2x+2xC​​hh+2x+2xC​)​​→⎩⎨⎧​ϕAe​(ξ)=(xC​−xA​)(xB​−xA​)(xC​−x)(xB​−x)​ϕBe​(ξ)=(xA​−xC​)(xB​−x−C)(xA​−x)(xB​−x)​ϕCe​(ξ)=(xA​−xB​)(xC​−xB​)(xA​−x)(xC​−x)​​

Procedure: Compute Kkj=∫01xˉ1/2ϕj′xˉϕj′xˉdxˉK_{kj}=\int_0^1 \bar{x}^{1/2}\phi_j'\bar{x}\phi_j'\bar{x}d\bar{x}Kkj​=∫01​xˉ1/2ϕj′​xˉϕj′​xˉdxˉ after normalization

[∫0hxˉϕ1′(xˉ)ϕ1′(xˉ)dxˉ∫0hxˉϕ1′(xˉ)ϕ2′(xˉ)dxˉ∫0hxˉϕ1′(xˉ)ϕ3′(xˉ)dxˉ∫0hxˉϕ2′(xˉ)ϕ1′(xˉ)dxˉ∫0hxˉϕ2′(xˉ)ϕ2′(xˉ)dxˉ∫0hxˉϕ2′(xˉ)ϕ3′(xˉ)dxˉ∫0hxˉϕ3′(xˉ)ϕ1′(xˉ)dxˉ∫0hxˉϕ3′(xˉ)ϕ2′(xˉ)dxˉ∫0hxˉϕ3′(xˉ)ϕ3′(xˉ)dxˉ]\left[ \begin{array}{ccc} \int_0^h \sqrt{\bar{x}}\phi_1'(\bar{x})\phi_1'(\bar{x})d\bar{x} & \int_0^h \sqrt{\bar{x}}\phi_1'(\bar{x})\phi_2'(\bar{x})d\bar{x} & \int_0^h \sqrt{\bar{x}}\phi_1'(\bar{x})\phi_3'(\bar{x})d\bar{x} \\ \int_0^h \sqrt{\bar{x}}\phi_2'(\bar{x})\phi_1'(\bar{x})d\bar{x} & \int_0^h \sqrt{\bar{x}}\phi_2'(\bar{x})\phi_2'(\bar{x})d\bar{x} & \int_0^h \sqrt{\bar{x}}\phi_2'(\bar{x})\phi_3'(\bar{x})d\bar{x} \\ \int_0^h \sqrt{\bar{x}}\phi_3'(\bar{x})\phi_1'(\bar{x})d\bar{x} & \int_0^h \sqrt{\bar{x}}\phi_3'(\bar{x})\phi_2'(\bar{x})d\bar{x} & \int_0^h \sqrt{\bar{x}}\phi_3'(\bar{x})\phi_3'(\bar{x})d\bar{x} \\ \end{array} \right]⎣⎡​∫0h​xˉ​ϕ1′​(xˉ)ϕ1′​(xˉ)dxˉ∫0h​xˉ​ϕ2′​(xˉ)ϕ1′​(xˉ)dxˉ∫0h​xˉ​ϕ3′​(xˉ)ϕ1′​(xˉ)dxˉ​∫0h​xˉ​ϕ1′​(xˉ)ϕ2′​(xˉ)dxˉ∫0h​xˉ​ϕ2′​(xˉ)ϕ2′​(xˉ)dxˉ∫0h​xˉ​ϕ3′​(xˉ)ϕ2′​(xˉ)dxˉ​∫0h​xˉ​ϕ1′​(xˉ)ϕ3′​(xˉ)dxˉ∫0h​xˉ​ϕ2′​(xˉ)ϕ3′​(xˉ)dxˉ∫0h​xˉ​ϕ3′​(xˉ)ϕ3′​(xˉ)dxˉ​⎦⎤​

Compute Ckj=2∫01ϕj(xˉ)ϕk(xˉ)dxˉC_{kj}=2\int_0^1\phi_j(\bar{x})\phi_k(\bar{x})d\bar{x}Ckj​=2∫01​ϕj​(xˉ)ϕk​(xˉ)dxˉ

[∫0hϕ1(xˉ)ϕ1(xˉ)dxˉ∫0hϕ1(xˉ)ϕ2(xˉ)dxˉ∫0hϕ1(xˉ)ϕ3(xˉ)dxˉ∫0hϕ2(xˉ)ϕ1(xˉ)dxˉ∫0hϕ2(xˉ)ϕ2(xˉ)dxˉ∫0hϕ2(xˉ)ϕ3(xˉ)dxˉ∫0hϕ3(xˉ)ϕ3(xˉ)dxˉ∫0hϕ3(xˉ)ϕ2(xˉ)dxˉ∫0hϕ3(xˉ)ϕ3(xˉ)dxˉ]\left [ \begin{array}{ccc} \int_0^h \phi_1(\bar{x})\phi_1(\bar{x})d\bar{x} &\int_0^h \phi_1(\bar{x})\phi_2(\bar{x})d\bar{x} &\int_0^h \phi_1(\bar{x})\phi_3(\bar{x})d\bar{x} \\ \int_0^h \phi_2(\bar{x})\phi_1(\bar{x})d\bar{x} &\int_0^h \phi_2(\bar{x})\phi_2(\bar{x})d\bar{x} &\int_0^h \phi_2(\bar{x})\phi_3(\bar{x})d\bar{x} \\ \int_0^h \phi_3(\bar{x})\phi_3(\bar{x})d\bar{x} &\int_0^h \phi_3(\bar{x})\phi_2(\bar{x})d\bar{x} &\int_0^h \phi_3(\bar{x})\phi_3(\bar{x})d\bar{x} \\ \end{array} \right]⎣⎡​∫0h​ϕ1​(xˉ)ϕ1​(xˉ)dxˉ∫0h​ϕ2​(xˉ)ϕ1​(xˉ)dxˉ∫0h​ϕ3​(xˉ)ϕ3​(xˉ)dxˉ​∫0h​ϕ1​(xˉ)ϕ2​(xˉ)dxˉ∫0h​ϕ2​(xˉ)ϕ2​(xˉ)dxˉ∫0h​ϕ3​(xˉ)ϕ2​(xˉ)dxˉ​∫0h​ϕ1​(xˉ)ϕ3​(xˉ)dxˉ∫0h​ϕ2​(xˉ)ϕ3​(xˉ)dxˉ∫0h​ϕ3​(xˉ)ϕ3​(xˉ)dxˉ​⎦⎤​

Solve for αk\alpha_kαk​ in (Kkj+Ckj)αk=fk→αk=(Kkj+Ckj)−1fk(K_{kj}+C_{kj})\alpha_k = f_k \to \alpha_k=(K_{kj}+C_{kj})^{-1}f_k(Kkj​+Ckj​)αk​=fk​→αk​=(Kkj​+Ckj​)−1fk​ Approximated Solution: u^∼uN=∑k=1Nαk(xˉ)\hat{u} \sim u_N=\sum_{k=1}^N \alpha_k(\bar{x})u^∼uN​=∑k=1N​αk​(xˉ)

§ Discussion:

  • Approximated solution using quadratic basic function converges to the analytical solution quicker than linear functions.
  • We generally work with the weak form to minimize the residual
  • The smaller the mesh, the more accurate u(x,ϕ)u(x,\phi)u(x,ϕ) will be
  • In the discussion of error analysis, quadratic algorithm yields a smaller error than linear due to a larger big O.

We first note the symmetry of the membrane and simplify the model by considering only the first quadrant. Equation of Ellipse is (xa)2+(yb)2=1(\frac{x}{a})^2+(\frac{y}{b})^2=1(ax​)2+(by​)2=1 We segment each of the quadrant into two individual meshes: Biquadratic Quadralateral and Bilinear Triangle Rectangular Element: Nodes[1  2  3  5  6  7  8  9  0]Nodes [1 \;2 \;3 \;5 \;6 \;7 \;8 \;9 \;0]Nodes[123567890] Triangular Element: Nodes[3  4  12  11  10  7]Nodes [3 \;4 \;12 \;11 \;10 \;7]Nodes[341211107]

§ Procedure

The following demonstrates the procedure in calculating the stiffness matrix and loading vector of the elements.

  1. Choose Ω\OmegaΩ and Φj\Phi_jΦj​, j=1,2,...,Nej=1,2,...,N_ej=1,2,...,Ne​ and specify the x-y coordinates (x1,y1),(x2,y2),...,(xN,yN)(x_1,y_1),(x_2,y_2),...,(x_N,y_N)(x1​,y1​),(x2​,y2​),...,(xN​,yN​) of nodal points of each element.
  2. Specify a set of NiN_iNi​ integration points (ξl,ηl),  l=1,2,...,Nl(\xi_l,\eta_l), \; l=1,2,...,N_l(ξl​,ηl​),l=1,2,...,Nl​ and quadrature weights for Ω\OmegaΩ}
  3. Calculate the values of Φj,∂Φj/∂ξ,∂Φj/∂η\Phi_j, \partial \Phi_j / \partial \xi, \partial \Phi_j / \partial \etaΦj​,∂Φj​/∂ξ,∂Φj​/∂η at the integration points.}
  4. Calculate the values of x=x(ξ,η),y=y(ξ,η)x=x(\xi,\eta), y=y(\xi,\eta)x=x(ξ,η),y=y(ξ,η) and their derivatives at the integration points.}
  5. Calculate the values of the Jacobian and the functions ∂ξ/∂x,∂ξ/∂y,∂η/∂x,∂η/∂y\partial \xi /\partial x, \partial \xi / \partial y, \partial \eta / \partial x, \partial \eta / \partial y∂ξ/∂x,∂ξ/∂y,∂η/∂x,∂η/∂y}
  6. Compute ∂ϕje/∂x\partial \phi_j^e / \partial x∂ϕje​/∂x and ∂ϕje/∂y\partial \phi_j^e / \partial y∂ϕje​/∂y}
  7. Calculate the values of k,bk, bk,b and fff We may skip this step if we assume k=f=1k=f=1k=f=1
  8. Using the results of steps 3 to 7, calculate the values of the integrands at the integration points and multiply each by wi∣J(ξl,ηl)∣w_i|\mathbf{J}(\xi_l,\eta_l)|wi​∣J(ξl​,ηl​)∣
  9. Sum the numbers to obtain kijek_{ij}^ekije​ and fief_i^efie​

§ Torsional Properties

Physical quantities of interest, such as shear stresses and the relationship between the twisting moment, or torque, T, and the angle of twist θ\thetaθ, per unit length of the shaft, can be determined as follows, once the potential function u is known.

T=2Gθ∫ΩudΩT =2G\theta \int_\Omega ud\OmegaT=2Gθ∫Ω​udΩ

The shear stresses on the elliptical cross-section are given by the following expressions:

σxz=2Gθ∂u∂y,  σyz=−2Gθ∂u∂x\sigma_{xz}=2G\theta \frac{\partial u}{\partial y}, \; \sigma_{yz}=-2G\theta \frac{\partial u}{\partial x}σxz​=2Gθ∂y∂u​,σyz​=−2Gθ∂x∂u​ The stress function may be written as

ϕ=B{(xa)2+(yb)2−1)}\phi=B\lbrace(\frac{x}{a})^2+(\frac{y}{b})^2-1)\rbraceϕ=B{(ax​)2+(by​)2−1)} But since ∂2ϕ∂x2+∂2ϕ∂y2=−2Gθ\frac{\partial^2 \phi}{\partial x^2}+\frac{\partial^2 \phi}{\partial y^2}=-2G\theta∂x2∂2ϕ​+∂y2∂2ϕ​=−2Gθ We get that B=−a2b2Gθa2+b2B=-\frac{a^2b^2G\theta}{a^2+b^2}B=−a2+b2a2b2Gθ​ σ∗xz=∂ϕ∂y=2Byb2σ∗yz=−∂ϕ∂x=−2Bxa2\sigma*{xz}=\frac{\partial \phi}{\partial y}=\frac{2By}{b^2}\quad \sigma*{yz}=-\frac{\partial \phi}{\partial x}=-\frac{2Bx}{a^2}σ∗xz=∂y∂ϕ​=b22By​σ∗yz=−∂x∂ϕ​=−a22Bx​ T=2Gθ∫_ΩudΩ=−πBabT =2G\theta \int\_\Omega ud\Omega=-\pi B abT=2Gθ∫_ΩudΩ=−πBab

We can also verfiy that ϕ=B{(xa)2+(yb)2−1)}=ϕ=−a2b2Gθa2+b2{(xa)2+(yb)2−1)}\phi=B\lbrace(\frac{x}{a})^2+(\frac{y}{b})^2-1)\rbrace=\phi=-\frac{a^2b^2G\theta}{a^2+b^2}\lbrace(\frac{x}{a})^2+(\frac{y}{b})^2-1)\rbraceϕ=B{(ax​)2+(by​)2−1)}=ϕ=−a2+b2a2b2Gθ​{(ax​)2+(by​)2−1)}

The 27-node hexahedron is the analog of the 8-node “serendipity” quadrilateral For example, the general formulas for the midside nodes are Nj=14(1−ξ2)(1+ηjη)(1+ςjς)N_j=\frac{1}{4}(1-\xi^2)(1+\eta_j\eta)(1+\varsigma_j\varsigma)Nj​=41​(1−ξ2)(1+ηj​η)(1+ςj​ς)

Nj=14(1+ξjξ)(1−η2)(1+ςjς)N_j=\frac{1}{4}(1+\xi_j\xi)(1-\eta^2)(1+\varsigma_j\varsigma)Nj​=41​(1+ξj​ξ)(1−η2)(1+ςj​ς)

Nj=14(1+ξjξ)(1+ηjη)(1−ς2)N_j=\frac{1}{4}(1+\xi_j\xi)(1+\eta_j\eta)(1-\varsigma^2)Nj​=41​(1+ξj​ξ)(1+ηj​η)(1−ς2)

Hexahedral element with tri-quadratic approximation functions

N1=18(1−ξ)(1−η)(1−ς)N_1=\frac{1}{8}(1-\xi)(1-\eta)(1-\varsigma)N1​=81​(1−ξ)(1−η)(1−ς)

N2=18(1+ξ)(1−η)(1−ς)N_2=\frac{1}{8}(1+\xi)(1-\eta)(1-\varsigma)N2​=81​(1+ξ)(1−η)(1−ς)

N3=18(1+ξ)(1+η)(1−ς)N_3=\frac{1}{8}(1+\xi)(1+\eta)(1-\varsigma)N3​=81​(1+ξ)(1+η)(1−ς)

N4=18(1−ξ)(1+η)(1−ςN_4=\frac{1}{8}(1-\xi)(1+\eta)(1-\varsigmaN4​=81​(1−ξ)(1+η)(1−ς

N5=18(1−ξ)(1−η)(1+ς)N_5=\frac{1}{8}(1-\xi)(1-\eta)(1+\varsigma)N5​=81​(1−ξ)(1−η)(1+ς)

N6=18(1+ξ)(1−η)(1+ς)N_6=\frac{1}{8}(1+\xi)(1-\eta)(1+\varsigma)N6​=81​(1+ξ)(1−η)(1+ς)

N7=18(1+ξ)(1+η)(1+ς)N_7=\frac{1}{8}(1+\xi)(1+\eta)(1+\varsigma)N7​=81​(1+ξ)(1+η)(1+ς)

N8=18(1−ξ)(1+η)(1+ς)N_8=\frac{1}{8}(1-\xi)(1+\eta)(1+\varsigma)N8​=81​(1−ξ)(1+η)(1+ς)

N9=14(1−ξ2)(1−η)(1−ς)N_9=\frac{1}{4}(1-\xi^2)(1-\eta)(1-\varsigma)N9​=41​(1−ξ2)(1−η)(1−ς)

N10=14(1+ξ)(1−η2)(1−ς)N_{10}=\frac{1}{4}(1+\xi)(1-\eta^2)(1-\varsigma)N10​=41​(1+ξ)(1−η2)(1−ς)

N11=14(1−ξ2)(1+η)(1−ς)N_{11}=\frac{1}{4}(1-\xi^2)(1+\eta)(1-\varsigma)N11​=41​(1−ξ2)(1+η)(1−ς)

N12=14(1−ξ)(1−η2)(1−ς)N_{12}=\frac{1}{4}(1-\xi)(1-\eta^2)(1-\varsigma)N12​=41​(1−ξ)(1−η2)(1−ς)

N13=14(1+ξ)(1−η)(1+ς2)N_{13}=\frac{1}{4}(1+\xi)(1-\eta)(1+\varsigma^2)N13​=41​(1+ξ)(1−η)(1+ς2)

N14=14(1+ξ)(1−η2)(1+ς2)N_{14}=\frac{1}{4}(1+\xi)(1-\eta^2)(1+\varsigma^2)N14​=41​(1+ξ)(1−η2)(1+ς2)

N15=14(1−ξ2)(1+η)(1+ς)N_{15}=\frac{1}{4}(1-\xi^2)(1+\eta)(1+\varsigma)N15​=41​(1−ξ2)(1+η)(1+ς)

N16=14(1−ξ)(1−η2)(1+ς)N_{16}=\frac{1}{4}(1-\xi)(1-\eta^2)(1+\varsigma)N16​=41​(1−ξ)(1−η2)(1+ς)

N17=14(1−ξ)(1−η)(1−ς2)N_{17}=\frac{1}{4}(1-\xi)(1-\eta)(1-\varsigma^2)N17​=41​(1−ξ)(1−η)(1−ς2)

N18=14(1+ξ)(1−η2)(1−ς2)N_{18}=\frac{1}{4}(1+\xi)(1-\eta^2)(1-\varsigma^2)N18​=41​(1+ξ)(1−η2)(1−ς2)

N19=14(1+ξ)(1+η)(1−ς2)N_{19}=\frac{1}{4}(1+\xi)(1+\eta)(1-\varsigma^2)N19​=41​(1+ξ)(1+η)(1−ς2)

N20=14(1−ξ)(1+η2)(1−ς2)N_{20}=\frac{1}{4}(1-\xi)(1+\eta^2)(1-\varsigma^2)N20​=41​(1−ξ)(1+η2)(1−ς2)

N21=12(1−ξ2)(1−η2)(1−ς)N_{21}=\frac{1}{2}(1-\xi^2)(1-\eta^2)(1-\varsigma)N21​=21​(1−ξ2)(1−η2)(1−ς)

N22=12(1−ξ2)(1−η2)(1+ς)N_{22}=\frac{1}{2}(1-\xi^2)(1-\eta^2)(1+\varsigma)N22​=21​(1−ξ2)(1−η2)(1+ς)

N23=12(1−ξ2)(1−η)(1−ς2)N_{23}=\frac{1}{2}(1-\xi^2)(1-\eta)(1-\varsigma^2)N23​=21​(1−ξ2)(1−η)(1−ς2)

N24=12(1+ξ2)(1−η2)(1−ς2)N_{24}=\frac{1}{2}(1+\xi^2)(1-\eta^2)(1-\varsigma^2)N24​=21​(1+ξ2)(1−η2)(1−ς2)

N25=12(1−ξ2)(1+η)(1−ς2)N_{25}=\frac{1}{2}(1-\xi^2)(1+\eta)(1-\varsigma^2)N25​=21​(1−ξ2)(1+η)(1−ς2)

N26=12(1−ξ)(1−η2)(1−ς2)N_{26}=\frac{1}{2}(1-\xi)(1-\eta^2)(1-\varsigma^2)N26​=21​(1−ξ)(1−η2)(1−ς2)

N27=(1−ξ2)(1−η2)(1−ς2)N_{27}=(1-\xi^2)(1-\eta^2)(1-\varsigma^2)N27​=(1−ξ2)(1−η2)(1−ς2)

§ Bending of a Uniform, Homogeneous Elastic Beam (Euler-Bernoulli Theory)

Strong Form: ∫0L{(EIw′′)′′−q}vdx−{−(EIw′′)(L)−ML}v′(L)+{(EIw′′)(L)−vL}v(L)=0∀  vs.t  v(0)=0,  v′(0)=0\int_0^L\lbrace (EIw'')''-q\rbrace vdx-\lbrace -(EIw'')(L)-M_L\rbrace v'(L)+\lbrace (EIw'')(L)-v_L\rbrace v(L)=0 \quad \forall \;v \quad s.t \; v(0)=0, \; v'(0)=0∫0L​{(EIw′′)′′−q}vdx−{−(EIw′′)(L)−ML​}v′(L)+{(EIw′′)(L)−vL​}v(L)=0∀vs.tv(0)=0,v′(0)=0

Weak Form:

∫0LEIw′′v′′dx−∫0Lqvdx+MLv′(L)−vLv(L)=0∀  vs.t  v(0)=0,  v′(0)=0\int_0^L EIw''v''dx-\int_0^L qvdx+M_Lv'(L)-v_Lv(L)=0 \quad \forall \; v \quad s.t \; v(0)=0, \; v'(0)=0∫0L​EIw′′v′′dx−∫0L​qvdx+ML​v′(L)−vL​v(L)=0∀vs.tv(0)=0,v′(0)=0

Principal of Virtual Work

∫0LEIw′′v′′dx=∫0Lqvdx−MLv′(L)+vLv(L)\int_0^L EIw''v''dx=\int_0^L qvdx-M_Lv'(L)+v_Lv(L)∫0L​EIw′′v′′dx=∫0L​qvdx−ML​v′(L)+vL​v(L)

But since we don't have any applied moment of load at the supported end,our governing equation is actually

∫0LEIw′′v′′dx=∫0Lqvdx\int_0^L EIw''v''dx=\int_0^L qvdx∫0L​EIw′′v′′dx=∫0L​qvdx

The simplest Bernoulli-Euler plane beam element with two end nodes has four degrees of freedom ue=[v1θ1v2θ2]T\mathbf{u^e}=[v_1 \theta_1 v_2 \theta_2]^Tue=[v1​θ1​v2​θ2​]T.

Shape functions for this problem are conveniently expressed in terms of the dimensionless coordinate

ξ=2xh−1dxdξ=12hdξdx=2h\xi=\frac{2x}{h}-1 \qquad \frac{dx}{d\xi}=\frac{1}{2}h \qquad \frac{d\xi}{dx}=\frac{2}{h}ξ=h2x​−1dξdx​=21​hdxdξ​=h2​

§ Discussion:

  1. Maximum shear stress occurs at the extreme values, namely at a and b (as it approaches the boundary). Furthermore, from Figure 9, we see that greater max stress occurs at the end of the minor axis of the ellipse

  2. Stress along the two axes of the centerlines is symmetrical due to the geometric symmetry of the membrane. This is expected since the heaviest concentration is the middle and distributed evenly across the membrane.
